s.text: By 1970, the war was won militarily--or almost won.
By 1970, the war was won militarily--or almost won.
I'm not the first to make the point that Asia would probably be quite different today (and far worse off) if the United States had pulled out in, say, 1963 or 1964.

Passions were so great on both sides of the debate in the United States--I was antiwar at the time--that few people have honestly reconsidered their views or taken a fresh look at the war and its results.
When I look back now at the Vietnam era and recall what people (including me) thought and said, I think a dark cloud must have passed over the country.
I know Mike, but only slightly, and I haven't read any of his earlier books.
1) Yes, I basically agree with your characterization of the theme of the book.

With all the Vietnam books pouring out, I'd been looking for months for a revisionist take, one that didn't accept either of the liberal explanations (the United States missed opportunities for a settlement; the war was unwinnable) or the conservative one (politicians tied the hands of the military).
